item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Yes I found it terribly hard to try explain it well.

Each tile is 128 x 128
each entity on that tile has a position somewhere within that 128,
to get the tile number (counting from 0 to 13312(104 x 128) (104 is max tiles in a region and 128 is the size)),
we can by casting the result as an integer calculate the position of that object, (because of the way we do it here it will return the bottom left pixel, it may be an idea to factor in the x and y to get its absolute location after you have finished with the location).

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Ollie:

each tile has width and height 128, so the current playerx/y will be a factor of 128, and you must divide by 128 to get its tile location.

If the player is walking, it’s not a factor of 128 but you mean it right ;).

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client

item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

No, i meant why does dividing by 128 give the tile location. Sorry if that wasn’t clear.

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

00000000000000000000000010000000 = 128

7 (shift 7 places to the right)

00000000000000000000000000000001 = 1

&&

00000000000000000000000010000000 = 128

/ 128

00000000000000000000000000000001 = 1

Read full topic

@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:10, topic:308345”]it isnt an algorithm, >> 7 == / 128

the playerx/y is the exact location in the current region, dividing it by 128 gives the tile location[/quote]
Why 128?

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

it is “faster” (well, in this case it really is considering how many times it is executed), but it is probably present just as an effect of the obfuscation

most obfuscators will actually attempt to optimize. converting division/multiplication by powers of 2 into bit shifts is one of them

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

in the example you provided, pa.e (note: this changes every client revision) you would need to,

Field f = clientClassLoader.loadClass(“pa”).getDeclaredField(“e”);
f.setAccessible(true);
int baseX = f.getInt(null);

this can be easily gotten because it is static.

for the playerX, which is needed to find the absolute coordinate of the player is stored in the character class(or whatever be your naming schema) and needs to be reflected with the instance of your player.

I cannot provide the code for you, as you will learn more if you try.
take a look around these forums there’s a few “reflection” examples laying about.

once you have all the variables, the value can be worked out

int myX = baseX + (playerX >> 7);
int myY = baseY + (playerY >> 7);

or something similar(can’t remember exactly).

edit:

qauters:

shift right ;), but other then that it’s true.

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Integer.MAX_VALUE Integer.MAX_VALUE
item.description:
@Integer.MAX_VALUE wrote:

Thank you so much :)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 14, 2009, 06:07:29 am[/size][hr]OK, now that I got the instance of class (with your aid) I have tried to get the player’s absolute coordinates. So I reflected the fields of the client class and its instance with this code:

[code]for (Field field : rsclient.getDeclaredFields()) {
field.setAccessible(true);

if(field.get(rsclientIns) != null) {
	System.out.println(field.getType().getName() + " " + field.getName() + " = " + field.get(rsclientIns).toString());
}

}[/code]
And I got the following:

int F = 0 sg V = lo@ed662d int W = 114 int X = 0 int Z = 0 int ab = 0 int bb = 0 int cb = 0 int db = 0 nq eb = nq@42552c int fb = 0 int gb = 114 int hb = 108 int ib = 0 int jb = 0 int kb = 0 int lb = 0 int mb = 6 no nb = no@e5bbd6 boolean ob = false
Now where are the coordinates hidden in?
In a tutorial it says pa.e for BaseX but I can’t find it here.

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Class client = app.getComponentAt(1, 1).getFocusListeners()[0].getClass();

and to find the other classes, which you will need:

ClassLoader clientClassLoaer = client.getClassLoader();

Class clazz = clientClassLoader.loadClass(“clazz”);

Read full topic

item.title: Instance of client
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:2, topic:308345”]http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,294949.0.html

it sux but the it will explain how to do what you want.

I could directly create an instance of it by using runescape.jar, but loading would take incredibly long then.

Wut?[/quote]

He is referring to the fact that unless you replace the classes the loader replaces yourself, simply running the client class in runescape.jar will be in unsigned mode so it has to download the required parts of the cache each time you start up (which is like 10mb or so).

Read full topic
